newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: ETHNIC HUNGARIANS PROTEST SLOVAK-ONLY REPORT CARDS.
newsitem.headline: ETHNIC HUNGARIANS PROTEST SLOVAK-ONLY REPORT CARDS.

text.p: Many ethnic Hungarian pupils in Slovakia refused to accept their year-end report cards on Friday because they were written only in Slovak rather than the traditional bilingual way.

The move to reject the Slovak-only reports was a protest against what the ethnic Hungarians consider to be a violation of their minority rights by the government of Premier Vladimir Meciar, according to leaders of the ethnic Hungarian community.
Slovakia has been battered by European Union and U.S. criticism over the Bratislava government's slowness to implement democratic reforms and improve its treatment of ethnic minorites.
"A more than 77-year long tradition of bilingual reports has been broken," Bela Bugar, leader of the ethnic Hungarian Christian Democrats Party, told the independent radio Twist.

"The current regime is behaving even worse than that of (Jozef) Tiso... which tolerated bilingual reports," Bugar, an opposition member of parliament said, referring to the president of the 1939-45 Slovak Nazi-puppet state.
TASR, the official Slovak news agency, reported that many ethnic Hungarian students in various spots in the south of the country had joined in the protest.
Slovakia's Education Ministry ordered only Slovak-language reports to be issued in elementary and secondary schools.
The directive applied also to schools in southern Slovakia where most of the 600,000-strong ethnic Hungarian minority live, many of whom use Hungarian as a teaching language.
The ministry based its decision on a 1995 state language law enacted for the east European country of five million people.

"The issue of single-language reports in Hungarian-language schools... is strictly according to the law which says all official documents must be in the state language," Gejza Sadecky, head of the ministry's school department, told TASR.
Many parents refused to send their children to school in protest against the move, while several Hungarian language schools administrators disobeyed official orders and issued bilingual reports.
Earlier this week, the EU called on Slovakia to withdraw a school handbook, published with EU financing, that denies the persecution of Slovak Jews during World War Two.
Meciar, attending an EU conference on Friday in Amsterdam on Friday, rejected the calls but agreed that the book would not be used as a text in Slovak schools. REUTER 271602 GMT jun 97
